class="RichTextArticleBody">          <div class="RichTextArticleBody-body">          <p>The Guardian has directed its staff to use “climate emergency” or “climate crisis” instead of “climate change” in news stories. </p>          <p>According to <a href="https://twitter.com/MarkDiStef/status/1129330642720829441" target="_blank">an internal email </a>the British newspaper — a proud bastion of liberalism — contends “climate change” sounds “rather passive and gentle when what scientists are talking about is a catastrophe for humanity.” </p>          <p>Rather than “climate skeptic," terms like “climate denier" or “climate science denier” should be used. The email said “global heating” should be used instead of “global warming." </p>          <div style="float: left; margin-right: 2em">           <div class="connatix" style="padding: 10px 0px; Roman,Times,serif;">       <a href="" style="color: #292b2c;" cnx-title="5" data-islink="true">Editorial Director Hugo Gurdon on the expanded Washington Examiner magazine</a>    </div>    <div class="cnx-sponsor" style="color: #636c72; font-size: 12px; line-height: 20px; font-family: Montserrat,-apple-system,system-ui,BlinkMacSystemFont,Segoe UI,Helvetica Neue,Arial,sans-serif; font-weight: normal;">Watch Full Screen to Skip Ads    </div>  </div> </div>          </div>          <p>The Associated Press Stylebook, which is the industry standard for most media outlets, <a href="https://blog.ap.org/announcements/an-addition-to-ap-stylebook-entry-on-global-warming" target="_blank">states</a>: "To describe those who don’t accept climate science or dispute the world is warming from man-made forces, use <i>climate change doubters</i> or <i>those who reject mainstream climate science</i>. Avoid use of <i>skeptics</i> or <i>deniers</i>."</p>          <p>While stopping short of an outright ban, Guardian editors told staff to "think twice" before including them in stories. </p>          <p>“We want to ensure that we are being scientifically precise in rooted facts, while also communicating clearly with readers on this very important issue,” the email to staff said. </p>          <p>Staff were also instructed to avoid using terms like "biodiversity" and "fish stocks." Instead, "wildlife" and "fish populations" should be used, respectively. </p>          <p>[<b>Also read:</b> <a href="https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/policy/energy/landmark-hearing-exposes-climate-change-gulf-among-republicans-and-democrats" target="_blank">Landmark hearing exposes climate change gulf among Republicans and Democrats</a>]</p>         </div>         </div>        </div>       </div>       <div class="ArticlePage-tagsActions col-md-12 col-lg-7 col-xl-8 d-inline-block float-md-left my-3">
